message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage is the condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass. This is followed by the other options, including fragmentation of the nucleus and membrane blebbing. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance occur in the late stages of irreversible cell damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass is the earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage. The other options are all signs of later stages of cell death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage is the condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass, also known as karyorrhexis. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance, nucleus fragmentation, and membrane blebbing are all signs of later stage damage.

We refer to the article "Pathology of cell injury" for help. The earliest sign of irreversible cell damage is condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass, also known as pyknosis. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance, fragmentation of the nucleus, and membrane blebbing from organelles are all signs that occur later on in the process of irreversible cell damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The earliest sign of irreversible damage in a cell is the condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass, also known as pyknosis. Other options, such as fragmentation of the nucleus and membrane blebbing, occur later in the process of cell death. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance occurs in the latest stage of cell death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Basophilic mass represents the earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage, known as karyorrhexis. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance is known as karyolysis and indicates late-stage damage. Fragmentation of the nucleus (karyorrhexis) and membrane blebbing from organelles are both later stages of irreversible cell damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The earliest sign of cell progression to irreversible damage is condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance is a later sign, following the basophilic mass. Fragmentation of the nucleus and membrane blebbing from organelles are also later signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage is the condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass, which is a characteristic of pyknosis. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance (karyolysis), fragmentation of the nucleus (karyorrhexis), and membrane blebbing from organelles are all later signs of irreversible damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Condensation of DNA into a basophilic mass is known as pyknosis and represents the earliest sign that a cell has progressed to irreversible damage in necrotizing fasciitis. Chromatin dissolution and disappearance, fragmentation of the nucleus, and membrane blebbing from organelles all occur later in the process of cell death.

Chromatin dissolution and disappearance occur later in the process of irreversible damage. Fragmentation of the nucleus and membrane blebbing from organelles are also later signs.
